yaml.title: Economic Valuation Report
yaml.subtitle: Coastal and Marine Ecosystem Goods and Services

markdown.markdown:
```{=html}

üí∞ Economic Valuation Report

Coastal and Marine Ecosystem Goods and Services
Report Date: March 30, 2026
üìã Executive Summary

This comprehensive economic valuation report assesses the monetary and non-monetary values of coastal and marine ecosystem goods and services in Mkuranga and Mkoani districts. Through integration of biophysical data and economic methodologies, the report provides evidence-based valuations essential for investment planning, policy development, and bio-economic modeling.

Study Area: Mkuranga and Mkoani Districts
Valuation Basis: USD currency (2026 baseline)
Methodologies: Market-based, revealed preference, and stated preference approaches

üåç Ecosystem Asset Classification
Spatial Mapping of Classified Assets
Ecosystem Type Area (ha) Status Value Significance
Mangrove Forests X,XXX Declining Very High
Coral Reefs XX,XXX Degraded Very High
Seagrass Beds X,XXX Stable High
Sandy Beaches XXX Eroding High
Open Water (productive) XX,XXX Declining productivity Very High
Mixed Wetlands X,XXX Threatened High
üìä Ecosystem Services Valuation
Total Baseline Ecosystem Service Value: USD X.X Million (Annual)
Valuation Period: 1-year baseline (2026 values)
Discount Rate: 10% (for present value calculations)
Provisioning Services
Service Production Volume Unit Value (USD) Annual Value (USD)
Marine Fisheries XX,XXX tons/year XXX/ton X,XXX,XXX
Aquaculture Production X,XXX tons/year XXX/ton XXX,XXX
Seaweed/Macro-algae XXX tons/year XXX/ton XXX,XXX
Salt Production XXX tons/year XX/ton XX,XXX
Construction Materials XXX cubic meters/year XXX/unit XX,XXX
Subtotal Provisioning Annual Value: X,XXX,XXX
Regulating Services
Service Biophysical Measure Unit Value (USD) Annual Value (USD)
Carbon Sequestration XX,XXX tons CO‚ÇÇ/year XX/ton CO‚ÇÇ XXX,XXX
Coastal Protection Protection value (avoided damage) Avoided loss value X,XXX,XXX
Water Filtration XX,XXX cubic meters/year X/cubic meter XXX,XXX
Nutrient Cycling N and P processing capacity Treatment cost avoided XXX,XXX
Climate Regulation Energy balance contribution Replacement cost value XXX,XXX
Subtotal Regulating Annual Value: X,XXX,XXX
Supporting Services
Service Description Valuation Method Annual Value (USD)
Habitat Provision Nursery for fish species Productivity linkage value XXX,XXX
Biodiversity Support Species diversity maintenance Existence value XXX,XXX
Primary Productivity Foundation for food web Food production linkage XXX,XXX
Subtotal Supporting Annual Value: XXX,XXX
Cultural Services
Service Description Valuation Method Annual Value (USD)
Recreation & Tourism Beach recreation, diving, tourism Travel cost method, willingness to pay XXX,XXX
Educational Value Research and learning opportunities Contingent valuation XX,XXX
Cultural Heritage Traditional practices and identity Stated preference XXX,XXX
Aesthetic Value Scenic beauty and landscape value Hedonic pricing XXX,XXX
Subtotal Cultural Annual Value: XXX,XXX
‚ö†Ô∏è Comparative Risk Analysis
Ecosystem Change Scenarios
Scenario Description Value Change Timeline
Status Quo Current trends continue -X% over 10 years By 2036
Degradation Accelerated ecosystem decline -X% over 10 years By 2036
Conservation Protected area expansion and management +X% over 10 years By 2036
Restoration Active ecosystem restoration +X% over 10 years By 2036
‚ö†Ô∏è Key Risk Findings:
  • Annual ecosystem value loss under status quo: USD XXX,XXX/year
  • Cumulative 10-year loss: USD X,XXX,XXX
  • Critical ecosystem services under threat: Fisheries, coastal protection, carbon sequestration
  • Irreversible changes risk: Coral reef collapse, mangrove loss leading to ecosystem regime shift
üîç Data Gaps & Additional Collection
Identified Data Gaps
  • Economic Data: Limited price series for some local products, informal sector valuation challenges
  • Biophysical Data: Incomplete historical ecosystem extent data, species population trends for some fauna
  • Social Data: Subsistence consumption values, cultural practice valuation complexities
  • Market Data: Informal trade value, non-market transaction documentation
  • Climate Data: High-resolution future projection scenarios, localized climate impacts
Additional Field Data Collection
  • Household willingness-to-pay surveys for ecosystem services
  • Market chain analysis and price tracking
  • Seasonal variation assessment for provisioning services
  • Expert elicitation for cultural and supporting service values
  • Climate scenario modeling and vulnerability assessment
üíµ Baseline Valuation Summary (2026 USD)
Annual Ecosystem Service Values (Baseline):
Provisioning Services: USD X,XXX,XXX
Regulating Services: USD X,XXX,XXX
Supporting Services: USD XXX,XXX
Cultural Services: USD XXX,XXX

TOTAL ANNUAL VALUE: USD X,XXX,XXX
Value per Hectare Analysis
  • Mangroves: USD X,XXX/ha/year (highest value per area)
  • Coral Reefs: USD X,XXX/ha/year
  • Seagrass Beds: USD XXX/ha/year
  • Open Water (productive): USD XXX/ha/year
  • Mixed Wetlands: USD XXX/ha/year
üë• Stakeholder-Validated Recommendations
Validation Process
  • Community stakeholder workshops (March 2026)
  • Government agency consultations
  • Private sector engagement sessions
  • Scientific peer review
  • Iterative feedback and refinement
Key Recommendations
  • Investment in Mangrove Conservation: High value justifies significant conservation investment
  • Fishery Management: Implement sustainable fishery practices to maintain provisioning service value
  • Coastal Protection: Integrate natural infrastructure (mangroves, reefs) into climate adaptation planning
  • Payment for Ecosystem Services: Design mechanisms to compensate communities for conservation
  • Sustainable Aquaculture: Promote diversified livelihoods aligned with ecosystem capacity
  • Monitoring & Enforcement: Establish systematic monitoring of ecosystem value changes
üéØ Support for Bio-Economic Modeling & Investment Planning

This valuation report provides the essential economic foundation for bio-economic modeling and investment planning:

  • Baseline values for cost-benefit analysis of conservation and development scenarios
  • Economic indicators for monitoring progress toward sustainability goals
  • Investment returns from ecosystem conservation and restoration
  • Trade-off analysis for competing land use options
  • Payment mechanisms for ecosystem service compensation
  • Economic case for blue economy development aligned with conservation
üéØ Conclusion

The economic valuation of coastal and marine ecosystem goods and services in Mkuranga and Mkoani districts reveals substantial economic values dependent on ecosystem integrity. These findings demonstrate the critical economic case for ecosystem conservation and sustainable resource management. The baseline valuation, combined with risk analysis, provides compelling evidence for investment in conservation and sustainable development pathways.

Economic Valuation Report | March 30, 2026

Local Marine Spatial Planning Initiative - Tanzania

‚Üê Back to Reports

```
